texts.shortText:
Colony consists of numerous, thin creeping stems (‘stolons’) forming tangled masses firmly attached to the substratum. The individual zooecia are erect, elongate and flask-shaped and attached to the stolon at intervals in pairs or clumps. Lophophores have only 8 tentacles. Colour transparent to pale yellow or brown when alive. 

Common, but inconspicuous and thus easily overlooked, also often confused as being a hydroid.
Individual zooecia about 1 mm tall, colonies may spread 10 cm or more across.

Global: Widespread across both North and South Atlantic Ocean, Pacific coast of Chile, New Zealand. May be introduced in habitats outside North Atlantic.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to False Bay.
Fouling species common creeping across the undersides of boulders in the intertidal and shallow subtidal. Also on ships hulls, pilings and jetties in harbours.

All bryozoans are filter feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.

Hermaphrodite. Single ova are brooded in the vacated tentacle sheaths of feeding zooids, after degeneration of the lophophore. Egg development takes 13-14 days and then the egg is released into the water column. Fertilisation takes place on release and the larvae have a brief planktonic life before settling to found a new colony. Colonies expand by extending the stems and budding new zooecia at their tips.
Few South African bryozoans have creeping stolons that are attached to the substratum, making this species fairly easy to identify. It is often misidentified as a hydroid though.
Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 10).
